what: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
title: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
text: R package HDNRA includes latest methods based normal-reference approach test equality mean vectors high-dimensional samples possibly different covariance matrices. HDNRA also used demonstrate implementation tests, catering two-sample problem, also general linear hypothesis testing (GLHT) problem. package provides easy user-friendly access tests. coded C++ allow reasonable execution time using Rcpp. Besides Rcpp, package strict dependencies order provide stable self-contained toolbox invites re-use. : Two real data sets HDNRA COVID19 corneal Seven normal-reference tests two-sample problem ZGZC2020.TS.2cNRT ZZ2022.TS.3cNRT ZZZ2020.TS.2cNRT ZWZ2023.TSBF.2cNRT ZZ2022.TSBF.3cNRT ZZGZ2021.TSBF.2cNRT ZZZ2023.TSBF.2cNRT Five normal-reference tests GLHT problem HDNRA ZGZ2017.GLHT.2cNRT ZZ2022.GLHT.3cNRT ZZZ2022.GLHT.2cNRT ZZ2022.GLHTBF.3cNRT ZZG2022.GLHTBF.2cNRT Four existing tests two-sample problem HDNRA BS1996.TS.NART SD2008.TS.NABT CQ2010.TSBF.NABT SKK2013.TSBF.NABT Five existing tests GLHT problem HDNRA FHW2004.GLHT.NABT SF2006.GLHT.NABT YS2012.GLHT.NABT ZGZ2017.GLHTBF.NABT S2007.ks.NABT

title: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
text: can install load recent development version HDNRA GitHub :
code: # Installing from GitHub requires you first install the devtools or remotes package install.packages("devtools") # Or install.packages("remotes")  # install the most recent development version from GitHub devtools::install_github("nie23wp8738/HDNRA") # Or remotes::install_github("nie23wp8738/HDNRA") # load the most recent development version from GitHub library(HDNRA)

title: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
code: library(HDNRA)

title: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
text: Package HDNRA comes two real data sets:
code: # A COVID19 data set from NCBI with ID GSE152641 for the two-sample problem. ?COVID19 data(COVID19) dim(COVID19) #> [1]    87 20460 group1 <- as.matrix(COVID19[c(2:19, 82:87), ]) ## healthy group dim(group1) #> [1]    24 20460 group2 <- as.matrix(COVID19[-c(1:19, 82:87), ]) ## COVID-19 patients dim(group2) #> [1]    62 20460  # A corneal data set acquired during a keratoconus study for the GLHT problem. ?corneal data(corneal) dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group dim(group1) #> [1]   43 2000 group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group dim(group2) #> [1]   14 2000 group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group dim(group3) #> [1]   21 2000 group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group dim(group4) #> [1]   72 2000

title: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
text: simple example use one normal-reference tests ZWZ2023.TSBF.2cNRT using data set COVID19:
code: data("COVID19") group1 <- as.matrix(COVID19[c(2:19, 82:87), ]) # healthy group1 group2 <- as.matrix(COVID19[-c(1:19, 82:87), ]) # patients group2 # The data matrix for tsbf_zwz2023 should be p by n, sometimes we should transpose the data matrix ZWZ2023.TSBF.2cNRT(group1, group2) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Zhu et al. (2023)'s test #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 Difference between two mean vectors is 0 #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          Difference between two mean vectors is not 0 #>  #> Data:                            group1 and group2 #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 24 #>                                  n2 = 62 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                20460 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[ZWZ] = 4.1877 #>  #> Approximation method to the      2-c matched chi^2-approximation #> null distribution of T[ZWZ]:  #>  #> Approximation parameter(s):      df1 =   2.7324 #>                                  df2 = 171.7596 #>  #> P-value:                         0.008672887

title: High-Dimensional Location Testing with Normal-Reference Approaches
text: simple example use one normal-reference tests ZZG2022.GLHTBF.2cNRT using data set corneal:
code: data("corneal") dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group p <- dim(corneal)[2] Y <- list() k <- 4 Y[[1]] <- group1 Y[[2]] <- group2 Y[[3]] <- group3 Y[[4]] <- group4 n <- c(nrow(Y[[1]]),nrow(Y[[2]]),nrow(Y[[3]]),nrow(Y[[4]])) G <- cbind(diag(k-1),rep(-1,k-1)) ZZG2022.GLHTBF.2cNRT(Y,G,n,p) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Zhang et al. (2022)'s test #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 The general linear hypothesis is true #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          The general linear hypothesis is not true #>  #> Data:                            Y #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 43 #>                                  n2 = 14 #>                                  n3 = 21 #>                                  n4 = 72 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                2000 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[ZZG] = 159.7325 #>  #> Approximation method to the      2-c matched chi^2-approximation #> null distribution of T[ZZG]:  #>  #> Approximation parameter(s):      df   = 6.1652 #>                                  beta = 6.1464 #>  #> P-value:                         0.0002577084

what: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT
title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT
text: Bai Saranadasa (1996)'s test testing equality two-sample high-dimensional mean vectors assuming two covariance matrices .

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT
code: BS1996.TS.NABT(y1, y2)

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT
text: y1 data matrix (\(n_1 \times p\)) first population. row represents \(p\)-dimensional observation. y2 data matrix (\(n_2 \times p\)) second population. row represents \(p\)-dimensional observation.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT
text: list class "NRtest" containing results hypothesis test. See help file NRtest.object details.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Bai Saranadasa (1996) proposed following centralised \(L^2\)-norm-based test statistic: $$T_{BS} = \frac{n_1n_2}{n} \|\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2\|^2-\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}),$$  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\) pooled sample covariance matrix. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{BS}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — BS1996.TS.NABT

title: Normal-approximation-based test for GLHT problem proposed by Fujikoshi et al. (2004) — FHW2004.GLHT.NABT
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Fujikoshi et al. (2004) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{FHW}=\sqrt{p}\left[(n-k)\frac{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_h)}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_e)}-q\right],$$ \(\boldsymbol{S}_h\) \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) matrices sums squares products due hypothesis error, respecitively. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{FHW}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for GLHT problem proposed by Fujikoshi et al. (2004) — FHW2004.GLHT.NABT
code: library("HDNRA") data("corneal") dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group p <- dim(corneal)[2] Y <- list() k <- 4 Y[[1]] <- group1 Y[[2]] <- group2 Y[[3]] <- group3 Y[[4]] <- group4 n <- c(nrow(Y[[1]]),nrow(Y[[2]]),nrow(Y[[3]]),nrow(Y[[4]])) X <- matrix(c(rep(1,n[1]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[2]), rep(0,sum(n)),             rep(1,n[3]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[4])),ncol=k,nrow=sum(n)) q <- k-1 C <- cbind(diag(q),-rep(1,q)) FHW2004.GLHT.NABT(Y,X,C,n,p) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Fujikoshi et al. (2004)'s test #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 The general linear hypothesis is true #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          The general linear hypothesis is not true #>  #> Data:                            Y #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 43 #>                                  n2 = 14 #>                                  n3 = 21 #>                                  n4 = 72 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                2000 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[FHW] = 6.4015 #>  #> Approximation method to the      Normal approximation #> null distribution of T[FHW]:  #>  #> P-value:                         7.694084e-11 #>

title: Normal-approximation-based test for one-way MANOVA problem proposed by Schott (2007) — S2007.ks.NABT
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following one-way MANOVA problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1=\cdots=\boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \quad \text { vs. }\; H_1: H_0 \;\operatorname{\; \; ture}.$$ Schott (2007) proposed following test statistic: $$  T_{S}=[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{H})/h-\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{E})/e]/\sqrt{N-1},  $$ \(\boldsymbol{H}=\sum_{=1}^kn_i(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_i-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}})(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_i-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}})^\top\), \(\boldsymbol{E}=\sum_{=1}^k\sum_{j=1}^{n_i}(\boldsymbol{y}_{ij}-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{})(\boldsymbol{y}_{ij}-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{})^\top\), \(h=k-1\), \(e=N-k\), \(N=n_1+\cdots+n_k\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{S}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample problem proposed by Srivastava and Du (2008) — SD2008.TS.NABT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Srivastava Du (2008) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{SD} = \frac{n^{-1}n_1n_2(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^\top \boldsymbol{D}_S^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2) - \frac{(n-2)p}{n-4}}{\sqrt{2 \left[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{R}^2) - \frac{p^2}{n-2}\right] c_{p, n}}},$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors,  \(\boldsymbol{D}_S\) diagonal matrix sample variance, \(\boldsymbol{R}\) sample correlation matrix \(c_{p, n}\) adjustment coefficient proposed Srivastava Du (2008). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{SD}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for GLHT problem proposed by Srivastava and Fujikoshi (2006) — SF2006.GLHT.NABT
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Srivastava Fujikoshi (2006) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{SF}=\left[2q\hat{}_2(1+(n-k)^{-1}q)\right]^{-1/2}\left[\frac{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{B})}{\sqrt{p}}-\frac{q}{\sqrt{n-k}}\frac{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{W})}{\sqrt{(n-k)p}}\right].$$ \(\boldsymbol{W}\) \(\boldsymbol{B}\) matrix sum squares products due error error, respectively, \(\hat{}_2=[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{W}^2)-\operatorname{tr}^2(\boldsymbol{W})/(n-k)]/[(n-k-1)(n-k+2)p]\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{SF}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

code: library("HDNRA") data("corneal") dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group p <- dim(corneal)[2] Y <- list() k <- 4 Y[[1]] <- group1 Y[[2]] <- group2 Y[[3]] <- group3 Y[[4]] <- group4 n <- c(nrow(Y[[1]]),nrow(Y[[2]]),nrow(Y[[3]]),nrow(Y[[4]])) X <- matrix(c(rep(1,n[1]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[2]), rep(0,sum(n)),             rep(1,n[3]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[4])),ncol=k,nrow=sum(n)) q <- k-1 C <- cbind(diag(q),-rep(1,q)) SF2006.GLHT.NABT(Y,X,C,n,p) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Srivastava and Fujikoshi (2006)'s test  #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 The general linear hypothesis is true #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          The general linear hypothesis is not true #>  #> Data:                            Y #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 43 #>                                  n2 = 14 #>                                  n3 = 21 #>                                  n4 = 72 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                2000 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[SF] = 6.4231 #>  #> Approximation method to the      Normal approximation #> null distribution of T[SF]:  #>  #> P-value:                         6.677982e-11 #>

title: Normal-approximation-based test for two-sample BF problem proposed by Srivastava et al. (2013) — SKK2013.TSBF.NABT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Srivastava et al. (2013) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{SKK} = \frac{(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{D}}^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2) - p}{\sqrt{2 \widehat{\operatorname{Var}}(\hat{q}_n) c_{p,n}}},$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors, \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}=\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_1/n_1+\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_2/n_2\) \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_i,=1,2\) diagonal matrices consisting diagonal elements sample covariance matrices. \(\widehat{\operatorname{Var}}(\hat{q}_n)\) given equation (1.18) Srivastava et al. (2013),  \(c_{p, n}\) adjustment coefficient proposed Srivastava et al. (2013). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{SKK}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for GLHT problem proposed by Yamada and Srivastava (2012) — YS2012.GLHT.NABT
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Yamada Srivastava (2012) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{YS}=\frac{(n-k)\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_h\boldsymbol{D}_{\boldsymbol{S}_e}^{-1})-(n-k)pq/(n-k-2)}{\sqrt{2q[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{R}^2)-p^2/(n-k)]c_{p,n}}},$$ \(\boldsymbol{S}_h\) \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) variation matrices due hypothesis error, respectively, \(\boldsymbol{D}_{\boldsymbol{S}_e}\) \(\boldsymbol{R}\) diagonal matrix diagonal elements \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) sample correlation matrix, respectively. \(c_{p, n}\) adjustment coefficient proposed Yamada Srivastava (2012). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{YS}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem proposed Zhang et al. (2017) — ZGZ2017.GLHT.2cNRT
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},\;=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Zhang et al. (2017) proposed following test statistic: $$ T_{ZGZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C \hat{\mu}}\|^2, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}=(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1^\top,\ldots,\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_k^\top)^\top\), \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZGZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Normal-approximation-based test for GLHT problem under heteroscedasticity proposed by Zhou et al. (2017) — ZGZ2017.GLHTBF.NABT
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Let  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i,=1,\ldots,k\) sample covariance matrices. Zhou et al. (2017) proposed following U-statistic based test statistic: $$ T_{ZGZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C \hat{\mu}}\|^2-\sum_{=1}^k h_{ii}\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i)/n_i, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\), \(h_{ij}\) \((,j)\)th entry \(k\times k\) matrix \(\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^\top(\boldsymbol{G}\boldsymbol{D}\boldsymbol{G}^\top)^{-1}\boldsymbol{G}\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZGZ}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Normal-reference-test with three-cumulant (3-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem proposed by Zhu and Zhang (2022) — ZZ2022.GLHT.3cNRT
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},\; =1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Zhu Zhang (2022) proposed following test statistic: $$ T_{ZZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C} \hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}\|^2-q \operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}), $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}=(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1^\top,\ldots,\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_k^\top)^\top\), \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\) usual pooled sample covariance matrix \(k\) samples. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Normal-reference-test with three-cumulant (3-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem proposed by Zhu and Zhang (2022) — ZZ2022.GLHT.3cNRT
code: library("HDNRA") data("corneal") dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group p <- dim(corneal)[2] Y <- list() k <- 4 Y[[1]] <- group1 Y[[2]] <- group2 Y[[3]] <- group3 Y[[4]] <- group4 n <- c(nrow(Y[[1]]),nrow(Y[[2]]),nrow(Y[[3]]),nrow(Y[[4]])) G <- cbind(diag(k-1),rep(-1,k-1)) ZZ2022.GLHT.3cNRT(Y,G,n,p) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Zhu and Zhang (2022)'s test #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 The general linear hypothesis is true #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          The general linear hypothesis is not true #>  #> Data:                            Y #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 43 #>                                  n2 = 14 #>                                  n3 = 21 #>                                  n4 = 72 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                2000 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[ZZ] = 122.1679 #>  #> Approximation method to the      3-c matched chi^2-approximation #> null distribution of T[ZZ]:  #>  #> Approximation parameter(s):      df    =   6.0490 #>                                  beta0 = -33.4163 #>                                  beta1 =   5.5243 #>  #> P-value:                         9.144893e-05 #>

title: Normal-reference-test with three-cumulant (3-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem under heteroscedasticity proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — ZZ2022.GLHTBF.3cNRT
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Let  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i,=1,\ldots,k\) sample covariance matrices. Zhang Zhu (2022) proposed following U-statistic based test statistic: $$ T_{ZZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C \hat{\mu}}\|^2-\sum_{=1}^kh_{ii}\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i)/n_i, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\), \(h_{ij}\) \((,j)\)th entry \(k\times k\) matrix \(\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^\top(\boldsymbol{G}\boldsymbol{D}\boldsymbol{G}^\top)^{-1}\boldsymbol{G}\).

code: library("HDNRA") data("corneal") dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group p <- dim(corneal)[2] Y <- list() k <- 4 Y[[1]] <- group1 Y[[2]] <- group2 Y[[3]] <- group3 Y[[4]] <- group4 n <- c(nrow(Y[[1]]),nrow(Y[[2]]),nrow(Y[[3]]),nrow(Y[[4]])) G <- cbind(diag(k-1),rep(-1,k-1)) ZZ2022.GLHTBF.3cNRT(Y,G,n,p) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Zhang and Zhu (2022)'s test #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 The general linear hypothesis is true #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          The general linear hypothesis is not true #>  #> Data:                            Y #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 43 #>                                  n2 = 14 #>                                  n3 = 21 #>                                  n4 = 72 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                2000 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[ZZ] = 121.1988 #>  #> Approximation method to the      3-c matched chi^2-approximation #> null distribution of T[ZZ]:  #>  #> Approximation parameter(s):      df    =   4.9334 #>                                  beta0 = -35.0606 #>                                  beta1 =   7.1068 #>  #> P-value:                         0.0004959474 #>

title: Normal-reference-test with three-cumulant (3-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for two-sample problem proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — ZZ2022.TS.3cNRT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhang et al.(2022) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZ} = \frac{n_1n_2}{n} \|\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2\|^2-\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}),$$  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\) pooled sample covariance matrix. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for two-sample BF problem proposed by Zhang et al. (2021) — ZZGZ2021.TSBF.2cNRT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhang et al.(2021) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZGZ} = \frac{n_1n_2}{n} \|\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2\|^2,$$  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZGZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for two-sample problem proposed by Zhang et al. (2020) — ZZZ2020.TS.2cNRT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhang et al.(2020) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZZ} = \frac{n_1n_2}{np}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{D}}^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2),$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors, \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}\) diagonal matrix sample covariance matrix. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture limiting distribution.

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem proposed by Zhu et al. (2022) — ZZZ2022.GLHT.2cNRT
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Zhu et al. (2022) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZZ}=\frac{(n-k-2)}{(n-k)pq}\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_h\boldsymbol{D}^{-1}),$$ \(\boldsymbol{S}_h\) \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) variation matrices due hypothesis error, respectively, \(\boldsymbol{D}\) diagonal matrix diagonal elements \(\boldsymbol{S}_e/(n-k)\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture limiting distribution.

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem proposed by Zhu et al. (2022) — ZZZ2022.GLHT.2cNRT

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for GLHT problem proposed by Zhu et al. (2022) — ZZZ2022.GLHT.2cNRT
code: library("HDNRA") data("corneal") dim(corneal) #> [1]  150 2000 group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) ## normal group group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) ## unilateral suspect group group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) ## suspect map group group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) ## clinical keratoconus group p <- dim(corneal)[2] Y <- list() k <- 4 Y[[1]] <- group1 Y[[2]] <- group2 Y[[3]] <- group3 Y[[4]] <- group4 n <- c(nrow(Y[[1]]),nrow(Y[[2]]),nrow(Y[[3]]),nrow(Y[[4]])) X <- matrix(c(rep(1,n[1]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[2]), rep(0,sum(n)),             rep(1,n[3]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[4])),ncol=k,nrow=sum(n)) q <- k-1 C <- cbind(diag(q),-rep(1,q)) ZZZ2022.GLHT.2cNRT(Y,X,C,n,p) #>  #> Results of Hypothesis Test #> -------------------------- #>  #> Test name:                       Zhu et al. (2022)'s test #>  #> Null Hypothesis:                 The general linear hypothesis is true #>  #> Alternative Hypothesis:          The general linear hypothesis is not true #>  #> Data:                            Y #>  #> Sample Sizes:                    n1 = 43 #>                                  n2 = 14 #>                                  n3 = 21 #>                                  n4 = 72 #>  #> Sample Dimension:                2000 #>  #> Test Statistic:                  T[ZZZ] = 5.5651 #>  #> Approximation method to the      2-c matched chi^2-approximation #> null distribution of T[ZZZ]:  #>  #> Approximation parameter(s):      df = 8.9706 #>  #> P-value:                         1.083822e-07 #>

title: Normal-reference-test with two-cumulant (2-c) matched $\chi^2$-approximation for two-sample BF problem proposed by Zhang et al. (2023) — ZZZ2023.TSBF.2cNRT
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhang et al.(2023) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZZ}=\frac{n_1 n_2}{np}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^{\top} \hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_n^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2),$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors, \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_n=\operatorname{diag}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_1/n+\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_2/n)\) \(n=n_1+n_2\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture limiting distribution.
